p: Probably the most recognizable quality of mints is their appealing fragrant scent, which is why they have been used since early times in embalming funerary rites. The embalming practice continued until the Middle Ages in Christian Europe but was reserved to the elite. In fact, mint was recently found among the embalmed remains of King Richard the Lionheart (1157–1199) [ 29] and of John Plantagenet of Lancaster, first Duke of Bedford (1389–1435) [ 30]. The purpose of using aromatic herbs, such as mints, in these practices was not only to create conditions for long-term body conservation but to also confer it a good odor, similarly to the body of Christ (i.e., the sanctity odor) [ 29].
